_coverage: Enhanced schema with pricing, nutrition base, and cooking method multipliers

_schema.canonicalUnit: Primary unit (g for solids, ml for liquids, whole for countable)
_schema.state: Product state: fresh | frozen | canned | dried | other

density.gPerCup: Grams per US cup (240ml), null if not applicable
density.gPerTbsp: Grams per tablespoon (15ml), null if not applicable
density.gPerTsp: Grams per teaspoon (5ml), null if not applicable

_schema.aliases: Array of common text variants for matching
_schema.tags: Optional classification tags for future use

pricing.averagePrice: Average price per retail unit in AUD
pricing.unit: Typical retail unit (kg, L, pack, bunch, etc.)
pricing.lastUpdated: ISO date of last price check

per100g.vitamins: Object with vitamin values (A, C, D, E, K, B12, etc.)
per100g.minerals: Object with mineral values (calcium, iron, magnesium, etc.)

nutritionBase.lastUpdated: ISO date of last nutrition data fetch

methodName.multipliers: Nutrition multipliers relative to raw (e.g., 1.1 = 10% increase)
methodName.notes: Description of preparation method and typical conditions
methodName.oilAbsorption: Grams of oil absorbed per 100g (for fried items)

raw.notes: Raw, uncooked state - baseline for all calculations

grilled.notes: Grilled over direct heat, typical 15-20% water loss, fat renders out

baked.notes: Gentler than grilling, less water and fat loss

multipliers.notes: Vegetables absorb more oil (15-25g per 100g)

fried.notes: Significant oil absorption (10-20g per 100g), major fat and calorie increase | Vegetables absorb more oil (15-25g per 100g)

multipliers.notes: Vegetables lose more water-soluble vitamins than meat

boiled.notes: Water-soluble vitamins leach into cooking water, minerals partially retained | Vegetables lose more water-soluble vitamins than meat

multipliers.notes: Steaming preserves vitamin C better in vegetables

steamed.notes: Minimal nutrient loss, best method for preserving vitamins | Steaming preserves vitamin C better in vegetables

air-fried.notes: Between grilling and frying - moderate oil absorption (2-5g per 100g)
